qualities: Fairness is a core requirement in machine learning model design and deployment.
A fair system should not disadvantage individuals or groups based on gender.
A fair system should not disadvantage individuals or groups based on ethnicity.
A fair system should not disadvantage individuals or groups based on socioeconomic background.
Bias can arise at multiple stages of the data science workflow.
Bias can arise during data collection.
Historical and social inequalities may be reflected in the data itself.
The data itself may reflect historical and social inequalities.
The data may reflect skewed representations of certain populations.
Skewed representations of certain populations may be reflected in the data.
Seemingly neutral choices can unintentionally amplify existing disparities.
Feature selection or normalization can unintentionally amplify existing disparities.
Model selection techniques can introduce bias.
Trainâ€“test splitting or cross-validation can introduce bias.
Bias can be introduced if the underlying data distribution is not carefully considered.
Classification models are often evaluated on accuracy and fairness-related criteria.
Classification models are evaluated on demographic parity.
Classification models are evaluated on equal accuracy.
Predictive performance is distributed equitably across different groups.
Improving fairness may affect overall model accuracy.
Achieving fairness in classification models requires trade-offs.
Explainability plays a crucial role in building trust in automated decision-making systems.
Stakeholders must be able to understand why a model produces a particular outcome.
Stakeholders must understand the outcome in high-stakes contexts.
Transparent explanations can help identify potential sources of bias.
Transparent explanations support accountability.
Robust explanations ensure that small changes in the input data do not lead to inconsistent justifications.
Robust explanations ensure that small changes in the input data do not lead to misleading justifications.
Ethical considerations guide the development of data science applications.
Ethical considerations include fairness.
Ethical considerations include transparency.
Ethical considerations include respect for human dignity.
Data science applications that fail to address ethical concerns risk undermining public trust.
Data science applications that fail to address ethical concerns risk causing harm.
Data science applications that perform well according to traditional technical metrics do not address ethical concerns.
